thread.title: Famous Game of Thrones tree tunnel damaged by Storm Doris
thread.title_full: Famous Game of Thrones tree tunnel damaged by Storm Doris

author: Rebecca Hawkes
title: Famous Game of Thrones tree tunnel damaged by Storm Doris
text:
Famous Game of Thrones tree tunnel damaged by Storm Doris Workmen clear a fallen tree from the Dark Hedges in County Antrim Credit: Steven McAuley/PA Wire Rebecca Hawkes 23 February 2017 • 2:19pm 
P art of Country Antrim's Dark Hedges, a tree-lined avenue made famous by the HBO fantasy drama Game of Thrones , has been destroyed by Storm Doris . 
The beech-lined pathway, used in the popular George RR Martin adaptation to represent the King' s Road out of King's Landing, dates back to the late 18th century and was planted by the Stuart family – members of whom previously ruled Scotland and later Great Britain and Ireland – according to Discover Northern Island . That time we walked on the King's Road from Game of Thrones #ireland #wanderlustwednesday https://t.co/REd50qQ0dh pic.twitter.com/MZiGwuAwSk — Karen L (@kcyalao) August 24, 2016 
S ince it appeared in the second season of the show, the destination – which was already popular with tourists thanks to its lonely beauty – has become something of a haven for Thrones fans. 
Social media reveals a number of people who, in the past few years, have decided to make like Arya (Maisie Williams) in Game of Thrones season two and take to the King's Road. A post shared by George Wang (@georgewang888) on Oct 30, 2016 at 12:13pm PDT Walking the King's Road and Other Game of Thrones Locations in #Ireland https://t.co/0592hiB9T9 #GameofThrones pic.twitter.com/ykTmgrB8ZR — Mike Gerrard (@Mike_Gerrard) September 16, 2016 Visited Dark Hedges today aka King's Road @GameOfThrones pic.twitter.com/OR4XE44oC0 — Amit Sharma (@amito1993) September 4, 2016 
L uckily, it looks as if the damage caused to the landmark so far hasn't been too devastating. A report from Belfast Live has said that just one tree has been felled, and that efforts are currently underway to remove it from the road. 
A number of other trees across the country have been felled by the violent storm, which has been reclassed as an an Explosive Cyclogenisis or "weather bomb", with expected wind speeds of up to 90 miles per hour.
